TextMultpleChoice.Question: What difficult choice did Arun likely face as a young man? Make an inference based on the narrative.
TextMultpleChoice.Answers: Whether he should work with the British who were occupying his homeland, or to work with other zamindars to expel the foreigners Whether to spend more time with his sister or more time working on a farm Whether to set sail on a British boat or stay in India Whether he should join resistance fighters in the spice islands or live a life of ease in his estate in India

PictureMultpleChoice.Question: Which of the maps is most useful to analyze the historical time period in this narrative?

TextMultiSelect.Question: Which of these conclusions can you reasonably draw from the narrative?
TextMultiSelect.Answers: Peasants in India were treated harshly by the British and their agents The British East India Company gained wealth from India India has a large population Arun's life history was a common one in India in historical times and today Arun rarely traveled out of his village
TextMultiSelect.policy: Score points when all answers are correct.

WordMatch.Question: Match the term to the correct definition.

WordPair.target: "Great Ruler" or "Prince" of an Indian State
Had to pay taxes to the local leaders and British

TextMultpleChoice.Question: What was the most important factor to explain why the peasants in the narrative paid taxes to Arun?
TextMultpleChoice.Answers: They were frightened of violence if they did not pay They worshiped Arun as a god-like figure Paying taxes was a good way to create a partnership with Britain Paying taxes on time likely would lead to a more prosperous life for the family They believed the government was a great help to the peasants
